title: How much technology is appropriate for students? - Quora

response.answer_text: We teach middle school. All of our students use Google Classroom, which means no one forgets about an assignment, no one ever loses an assignment, and the teacher can fan through a batch of work very cleanly. So all that’s good. Yet, there’s research suggesting that all the screen time is changing our kids, and it’s easy to find evidence that the changes are in many ways negative. Read Richard Louv’s Last Child in the Woods for a moving description of what we’re losing. That said, my instinct is that the horse is utterly out of the barn - this stuff’s endemic, and that’s the way it is. Given that, I think we are actually creating a new kind of person and we only dimly see the outlines of the new world we’re hurtling into. What to do, then? As a science teacher, naturally I harness these kid-skills and make my job easier and more effective. So on a day-to-day hands-on basis, the tech permeates and we roll with it. The deeper issue is limning their world to them - that is, “Hey, you have all this tech. It facilitates X, Y and Z. But now, let’s discuss the natural world. Let’s discuss how you are a techno-fish and have difficulty seeing yourself separate from all the tech. ‘Fish, meet Water. Water, this is Fish.’ So how does tech separate you from your human-ness, and above all, how can you maintain your humanity with all the screentime?” Get them thinking meta-cognitively, thinking about their thinking. Get them to see two world-possibilities: one, that “I am in all this tech; it works - what do I do to remain kind, thoughtful, aware, and capable of original thought?” And two, for some kids “Oh - everyone sure is in all this tech. What support is there for me as an outlier, consciously ordering my life to less tech than my peers, and possibly inhabiting the creative edge as a consequence?” “Fish, meet Water.” Tech’s a done deal. So let’s see where we are, where we’re going, and how to consciously be aware of our surroundings, even though virtual. Metacognition’s the key.

What a great question! The facts are that there is no way to say too much technology is “bad”. The challenge being sure if you use technology, that everyone has access to said tools. There are many advantages to using computers and such. For instance, a teacher using Google.doc chrome can have students working on a written assignment and watch all students working in real time on the assignment, keep students on task and offer corrections or encouragement. But if your classroom does not have Wi-Fi or there are only a few computers to share amongst 25-30 kids…. well no time to get work done. And considering in day-to-day life, most people will be working on computers to one degree or another, it behooves us to educate our kids o technology
